Title: A View of the River
Author: LB Leopold
APA_Citation: Leopold, L. B. (1994). A View of the River. Harvard University Press.
Description: With the Midwest under water, America had a chance to see how effectively it had" improved" its rivers. We've straightened and dredged them, revetted and rerouted them, made
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydrology,Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Hydraulic Geometry

Title: Analytical Stream Restoration Design Review Checklist
Author: R Starr, W Harman
APA_Citation: Starr, R. and W. Harman. 2015. Analytical Design Review Checklist Version 3. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Chesapeake Bay Field Office, Annapolis, MD. CBFO-S15-02.
Description: The Analytical Design approach is a subset of the broader Alluvial Channel Design Methodology described in Chapter 9 of the United States Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Engineering Handbook (NEH) 654. The theory supporting the Analytical Approach is that channel dimensions can be calculated from physically-based equations including continuity, hydraulic resistance, and sediment transport.
Tags: Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Hydraulic Geometry,Documents_Design Theory_Analytical Design,Documents__In stream Structures

Title: Applied Hydrology
Author: VP Singh, D Eng
APA_Citation: Singh, V. P., & Eng, D. (2017). Handbook of applied hydrology. McGraw-Hill Education.
Description: This industry-standard resource has been completely revised for the first time since Ven Te Chow's classic edition was published over 50 years ago. Compiled by a colleague of the late Dr. Chow and featuring chapter contributions from a "who's who" of international hydrology
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology

Title: Applied River Morphology
Author: DL Rosgen, HL Silvey
APA_Citation: Rosgen, D., & Silvey, H. L. (1996). Applied river morphology: Pagosa Springs. Colorado, Wildland Hydrology, 1481.
Description: For use in: watershed management applications, ecosystem assessment, cumulative effects analysis, fish habitat evaluation, assessment of river condition, river restoration, communication regarding river systems. This book is a generous and detailed explanation of the stream classification system and how it might be used to incorporate the observed processes of river mechanics into restoration designs that enhance the beauty and health of channels.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydrology,Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Hydraulic Geometry,Documents_Design Theory_Natural Channel Design,Documents__In stream Structures

Title: Bank Stabilization Design Guidelines
Author: DC Baird, L Fotherby, CC Klumpp, SM Sculock
APA_Citation: Baird, D. C., Fotherby, L., Klumpp, C. C., & Sculock, S. M. (2015). Bank stabilization design guidelines. Reclamation: Managing water in the west, 319.
Description: A goal of these guidelines is to increase considerations of sustainability and longterm feasibility, and to increase environmental effectiveness in bank stabilization designs. Most of the bank protection methods presented in this manual can be applied in ways that meet all three measures of a successful design: feasibility, sustainability and environmental effectiveness.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Stable ch design and Stabilization,Documents__Bank Stabilization,Documents__Channel Reconfiguration,Documents__Floodplain Reconnection,Documents__Large wood,Documents__Grade control,Documents__River training,Documents__In stream Structures

Title: Channel Restoration Design for Meandering Rivers
Author: PJ Soar, CR Thorne
APA_Citation: Soar, Philip J., and Colin R. Thorne. Channel restoration design for meandering rivers. ENGINEER RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CENTER VICKSBURG MS COASTAL AND HYDRAULICSLAB, 2001.
Description: A framework for channel restoration design is presented that attempts to bridge the divide between reconnaissance level geomorphological designs at one extreme and numerical modeling of hydrodynamics, sediment transport and morphological change at the other. Reestablishing equilibrium between the sediment supply and available transport capacity in the restored reach is the primary objective of the design framework. A geomorphic engineering approach is presented, which recognizes that the river is ultimately the best restorer of its natural morphology and should be allowed to participate in its own recovery. This is accomplished through designing an approximate channel mould, based on the broad dimensions of the river, and then allowing the river itself to develop the intricate cross-sectional detail and intra-reach morphological features to complete the recovery process. Geomorphic engineering provides a practical solution by striking a balance between empirical-statistical and analytical process-based methods.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydrology,Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Hydraulic Geometry,Documents_Design Theory_Stable ch design and Stabilization,Documents_Design Theory_Threshold channel design,Documents_Design Theory_Alluvial Channel Design,Documents_Design Theory_Analytical Design,Documents__In stream Structures,Documents_Misc_Particularly helpful

Title: Classification of Natural Rivers
Author: DL Rosgen
APA_Citation: Rosgen, D. L. (1994). A classification of natural rivers. Catena, 22(3), 169-199.
Description: A classification system for natural rivers is presented in which a morphological arrangement of stream characteristics is organized into relatively homogeneous stream types. This paper describes morphologically similar stream reaches that are divided into 7 major stream type categories that differ in entrenchment, gradient, width/depth ratio, and sinuosity in various landforms. Within each major category are six additional types delineated by dominate channel materials from bedrock to silt/clay along a continuum of gradient ranges. Recent stream type data used to further define classification interrelationships were derived from 450 rivers throughout the U.S, Canada, and New Zealand. Data used in the development of this classification involved a great diversity of hydro-physiographic/geomorphic provinces from small to large rivers and in catchments from headwater streams in the mountains to the coastal plains.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Natural Channel Design

Title: Computational Design Tool for Evaluating the Stability of Large Wood Structures
Author: M Rafferty
APA_Citation: Rafferty, Michael. "Computational design tool for evaluating the stability of large wood structures." USDA Technical Note TN-103.2 (2017).
Description: Large logs are often placed in streams to benefit aquatic and riparian-dependent fish and wildlife. When specifying the type of large wood structure to be used, restoration practitioners, planners, and local residents need to be assured that the constructed structures will likely remain in place under the expected conditions.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Analytical Design,Documents__In stream Structures

Title: Design for Stream Restoration
Author: FD Shields Jr, RR Copeland, PC Klingeman, MW Doyle, A Simon
APA_Citation: Shields Jr, F. D., Copeland, R. R., Klingeman, P. C., Doyle, M. W., & Simon, A. (2003). Design for stream restoration. Journal of Hydraulic Engineering, 129(8), 575-584.
Description: Stream restoration, or more properly rehabilitation, is the return of a degraded stream ecosystem to a close approximation of its remaining natural potential. Many types of practices (dam removal, levee breaching, modified flow control, vegetative methods for streambank erosion control, etc.) are useful, but this paper focuses on channel reconstruction. A tension exists between restoring natural fluvial processes and ensuring stability of the completed project. Sedimentation analyses are a key aspect of design since many projects fail due to erosion or sedimentation. Existing design approaches range from relatively simple ones based on stream classification and regional hydraulic geometry relations to more complex two- and three-dimensional numerical models. Herein an intermediate approach featuring application of hydraulic engineering tools for assessment of watershed geomorphology, channel-forming discharge analysis, and hydraulic analysis in the form of one-dimensional flow and sediment transport computations is described.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydrology,Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Stable ch design and Stabilization,Documents_Design Theory_Threshold channel design,Documents_Design Theory_Alluvial Channel Design,Documents_Design Theory_Analytical Design

Title: EPA National Rivers and Stream Assessments
Author: EPA
APA_Citation: National Rivers and Streams Assessment. (2022, June 17). US EPA. https://www.epa.gov/national-aquatic-resource-surveys/nrsa
Description: The National Rivers and Streams Assessment (NRSA) is a collaborative survey that provides information on the ecological condition of the nation’s rivers and streams and the key stressors that affect them, both on a national and an ecoregional scale.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Physico chemical,Documents_Knowledge Base_Biological Ecology,Documents_Evaluation_Physico chemical,Documents_Evaluation_Biological Ecology

Title: EPA Rapid Bioassessment Protocols for use in Streams and Wadeable Rivers
Author: MT Barbour
APA_Citation: Barbour, M. T. (2001). Rapid Bioassessment Protocols for Use in Steams and Wadeable Rivers: Periphyton. Benthic Macroinvertebrates and Fish.
Description: The Rapid Bioassessment Protocols (RBPs) are essentially a synthesis of existing methods that have been employed by various State Water Resource Agencies (e.g., Ohio Environmental Protection Agency [EPA], Florida Department of Environmental Protection [DEP], Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control [DNREC], Massachusetts DEP, Kentucky DEP, and Montana Department of Environmental Quality [DEQ]). Protocols for 3 aquatic assemblages (i.e., periphyton, benthic macroinvertebrates, fish) and habitat assessment are presented. All of these protocols have been tested in streams in various parts of the country.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Physico chemical,Documents_Knowledge Base_Biological Ecology,Documents_Evaluation_Physico chemical,Documents_Evaluation_Biological Ecology

Title: Estimation of roughness coefficients for natural stream channels with vegetated banks
Author: WF Coon
APA_Citation: Coon, W. F. (1998). Estimation of roughness coefficients for natural stream channels with vegetated banks (Vol. 2441). US Geological Survey.
Description: Roughness coefficients for 21 stream sites in New York state are presented. The site-specific relation between roughness coefficent and flow depth varies in a predictable manner, depending on energy gradient, relative smoothness (Rd50), and channel-vegetation density. The percentage of wetted perimeter that is vegetated is a useful indicator of when streambank vegetation can affect the roughness coefficient. To estimate the magnitude of this effect requires evaluation of the density and percent of submergence of vegetation.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics

Title: Fluvial Processes in Geomorphology
Author: LB Leopold, MG Wolman, JP Miller, EE Wohl
APA_Citation: Leopold, L. B., Wolman, M. G., Miller, J. P., & Wohl, E. E. (2020). Fluvial processes in geomorphology. Courier Dover Publications.
Description: Its primary emphasis is on subjects that were the focus of the authors' studies in both field and laboratory. Part I deals with the process of change in the evolving landscape. Part II explores process and form, and Part III, the effects of time. In Part I, the relation of geomorphology to field problems is analyzed in studies of a mountain block in a semiarid climate, a meandering river cut into bedrock, and benches along a sea coast. Part Two contains studies of weathering, climate, and such denudational processes as flooding and erosion.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Hydraulic Geometry

Title: Fluvial Processes in River Engineering
Author: HH Chang
APA_Citation: Chang, H. H. (1992). Fluvial processes in river engineering.
Description: This text collects and collates the significant advances in analytical methods for alluvial channel design, river morphology, and mathematical simulation of river channel changes. It presents a complete analytical treatment of river morphology and its responses to environmental and human-made changes from the engineering point of view. For professionals in flood control, bridge design, irrigation and waterways, this book is a current, comprehensive refresher and reference.
Tags: Documents_Knowledge Base_Hydraulics,Documents_Knowledge Base_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Design Theory_Alluvial Channel Design,Documents_Design Theory_Analytical Design

Title: Functional objectives for stream restoration
Author: Fischenich
APA_Citation: Fischenich, J. C. (2006). Functional objectives for stream restoration. ENGINEER RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CENTER VICKSBURG MS.
Description: The National Research Council (1996) defined restoration as “the return of the form and function of an ecosystem to its predisturbance condition…” This definition presents two challenges when working in today’s environment.
Tags: Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology

Title: Function-based rapid stream assessment methodology
Author: R Starr, W Harman, S Davis
APA_Citation: Starr, R., W. Harman, S. Davis. 2015. FINAL DRAFT Function-Based Rapid Field Stream Assessment Methodology. U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Chesapeake Bay Field Office, Annapolis, MD. CAFE S15-06.
Description: The primary purpose of this methodology is to provide MDE regulators with a function-based rapid stream assessment methodology to verify existing and proposed stream function-based conditions submitted by stream restoration permit applicants. However, it can be used for a variety of other purposes.
Tags: Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Physico chemical,Documents_Evaluation_Biological Ecology

Title: Function-Based Stream Restoration Project Process Guidelines with Appendices
Author: W Harman, R Starr, M Carter, K Tweedy, M Clemmons, K Suggs, C Miller
Description: Stream restoration efforts have increased significantly in the US over the past few decades and are now recognized as a billion-dollar industry. These restoration efforts stem from centuries of abuse as humans continue to alter the riverine landscape for a variety of purposes, including farming, logging, mining and development on the floodplain, and the subsequent need for channelization and flood control. These activities have significantly diminished the natural functions of our stream corridors.
Tags: Documents_Evaluation_Hydrology,Documents_Evaluation_Hydraulics,Documents_Evaluation_Sediment Transport,Documents_Evaluation_Geomorphology,Documents_Evaluation_Physico chemical,Documents_Evaluation_Biological Ecology
